title: Ausgrid live work ban: Power pole left in middle of Newcastle road
text:
Handy tips to cut the cost of your next energy bill

How to pay less for your electricity

Pole position is usually sought after — but not on this inner Newcastle street.

A power pole has been left in the middle of the road at the intersection of Foundry and Albert Streets in Wickham after council work stopped on the weekend.

Recent road works have seen the road widened and kerb set back, but the power pole has been left in the same spot.

“Just bizarre — what else can you say,” a local businessman named Warwick told news.com.au today.

“It’s been there for a week, they’ve been working on this for ages.

“Apparently installing a roundabout eventually. The designer certainly made a few boo-boos.”

City of Newcastle Council chief executive Jeremy Bath said it all boils down to electricity provider Ausgrid putting a temporary ban on “live work” after the death of an employee who was electrocuted in April.

Have you seen the random power pole in the middle of the road at Wickham? Tanya and Steve asked Newcastle Council CEO Jeremy Bath for a please explain. Listen to their chat in the comments below. Posted by Triple M Newcastle on Sunday, 27 October 2019

“Anything involving electricity, they will not touch,” Mr Bath told Triple M Newcastle this morning.

“So any time that we need — and we do a whole heap of work where we want Ausgrid to come in and actually turn something off essentially, like a telegraph pole so it can be relocated — Ausgrid say ‘Sorry, we can’t do it at the moment’.

“So our choices are we either do no work or we have to stage work such as what you’re seeing in Foundry St.”

I'm reporting on @RNBreakfast from Newcastle today, where the top story is the local council moved the kerb at an intersection in Wickham before @ausgrid shifted the power pole - and let me tell you folks this story is lighting up @CoxDan and @jen_marchant's switchboard. pic.twitter.com/DymlytvHah — Matt Bevan 🎙 (@MatthewBevan) October 27, 2019

Mr Bath said it was “incredibly frustrating” and the council would be asking Ausgrid to “temporarily overlook” the ban on live works to relocate the pole.

The council boss was quizzed over the sudden appearance of the barricades that are missing in some photographs taken of the scene.

He said they were always there but locals called the council over the weekend to say they had disappeared.

“We went out there and put the barricades back,” he told the radio station on Monday.

Ausgrid and the council have been contacted by news.com.au for comment.

The ban on “live works” was put into place after Robert Nicholls, 39, was rushed to Sydney’s Royal North Shore Hospital in a critical condition in April where he later died, according to the Electrical Trades Union.

He had been part of an Ausgrid crew replacing a low-voltage power pole in Lane Cove when he was electrocuted.

According to an update provided by Ausgrid in September, the process to assess the recommencement of live work was ongoing.

A number of tasks were expected to resume including maintenance and replacement of street lighting assets, connection and disconnection of service connectors, and work on or near extra low-voltage exposed conductors.
